Description: Kentucky Utilities, a coal-fired electric utility,  agreed to pay a $1.4 million civil penalty and spend approximately $135 million on pollution controls to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announce that Kentucky Utilities Company will spend $57 million to install a sulfuric acid mist emission control system, replace a coal-fired boiler, and pay a civil penalty of $300,000 to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations (CAA) at the Ghent Station facility in Ghent, Kentucky.
back pay award in unfair labor practices case

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on October 23, 2020 in response to an open records request.
Contained in data received from the agency on October 23, 2020 in response to an open records request.

Description: Louisville Gas & Electric Company agreed to permanent emission limits for the sulfuric acid mist that it emits from its Mill Creek Station, located in Jefferson County, Kentucky. LG&E also agreed to perform a congressionally authorized diesel-emissions reduction supplemental environmental project aimed at reducing ground-level emissions to resolve allegations that it emitted too much sulfuric acid mist in violation of the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission issued for public comment a settlement with PPL Electric Utilities Corp. that ends an informal investigation into violations of rules governing winter terminations and includes a $175,000 contribution by the company to its Operation Help program.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved a settlement agreement between the PUC's independent prosecutory staff and PPL Electric that includes $175,000 for the company's low-income program after an informal investigation into the utility's termination practices.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission finalized a settlement with PPL Electric Corp. that includes a $300,000 contribution to a low-income program and ends an informal investigation into an electric service termination that preceded a fatal fire in Steelton, Dauphin County.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission finalized two settlements with PPL Electric Utilities Inc. that include $471,000 in monetary penalties and contributions to low-income programs, as well as improvements to customer service procedures and training, ending two informal investigations into the company's termination practices.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission approved a $15,000 settlement stemming from an informal investigation of PPL Electric Utilities Inc. concerning a residential account that had been terminated for non-payment.
The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission finalized a $45,000 settlement with PPL Electric Utilities Corp. (PPL) regarding an informal investigation into a residential termination.

The Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission finalized a settlement with PPL Electric Utilities Corp. (PPL) that included a $60,000 civil penalty stemming from an investigation into restoration practices during an October 2011 snowstorm.

Louisville Gas & Electric Co. agreed to a $125,000 penalty to the Kentucky Public Service Commission in settlement of alleged safety violations that were uncovered during the PSC's investigation of a Dec. 6, 2011 natural gas explosion that destroyed a house in southern Jefferson County.

The Kentucky Public Service Commission fined Louisville Gas and Electric Co. $395,000 for a series of violations that led to the September 2014 rupture of a high-pressure natural gas pipeline in Goshen, Oldham County.
